etymologies: late 16th century: from Anglo-Latin pica (literally ‘magpie’), commonly identified with a 15th-century book of rules about Church feasts, but no edition of such a pica printed in ‘pica’ type is known

definitions: a unit of type size and line length equal to 12 points (about 1/6 inch or 4.2 mm).
shortDefinitions: unit of type size and line length equal to 12 points

definitions: a size of letter in typewriting, with 10 characters to the inch (about 3.9 to the centimeter).
shortDefinitions: size of letter in typewriting, with 10 characters to inch

etymologies: mid 16th century: modern Latin, from Latin, literally ‘magpie’, probably translating Greek kissa ‘magpie’, also ‘false appetite’

definitions: a tendency or craving to eat substances other than normal food (such as clay, plaster, or ashes), occurring during childhood or pregnancy, or as a symptom of disease

examples.text: adults with pica tend to be highly selective

shortDefinitions: tendency or craving to eat substances other than normal food, occurring during childhood or pregnancy
